creditline: The John B. Putnam Jr. Memorial Collection, Princeton University

texts.textentryhtml: The reductive aspects of Minimalism can found in the stark, highly finished shapes of Michael Halls' aluminum and bronze sculpture Mastodon VI. Named for the extinct animal that the artist encountered in the Badlands of Nebraska, the tusk-like tubular shapes evoke fossilized mammal bones.

bibliography.boilertext: Patrick Joseph Kelleher, Living with Modern Sculpture: the John B. Putnam, Jr., Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 1982).
bibliography.citation: Patrick Joseph Kelleher, Living with Modern Sculpture: the John B. Putnam, Jr., Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 1982)., 52–55

bibliography.citation: Karin Dienst, ed., Sculpture of Princeton University: including works from the John B. Putnam Jr. Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Published by the Office of Communications, in association with the Princeton University Art Museum, 2004)., 46–47, illus.

bibliography.boilertext: Jane McCarthy and Laurily K. Epstein, A guide to the sculpture parks and gardens of America, (New York, NY: Michael Kesend Pub., 1996).
bibliography.citation: Jane McCarthy and Laurily K. Epstein, A guide to the sculpture parks and gardens of America, (New York, NY: Michael Kesend Pub., 1996).
